items.text: When I look at ambiguous images, I tend to see people, animals, or other living things rather than abstract shapes.
items.rationale: Content in Rorschach scoring refers to what the respondent sees — the thematic category of the percept (human, animal, nature, object, etc.).

items.text: I frequently identify human figures or faces in random patterns like clouds or stains.
items.rationale: Human content (H) is a primary content category; this describes a tendency to produce human content responses.

items.text: My imagination tends to populate ambiguous scenes with animals — I see butterflies, bats, and bears where others see nothing.
items.rationale: Animal content (A) is the most common content category in Rorschach responses; this directly taps that tendency.

items.text: When interpreting vague images, I often describe anatomical or body-related things like bones, organs, or x-rays.
items.rationale: Anatomy content (An) is a specific content code reflecting preoccupation with internal body structures.

items.text: I tend to see violent or aggressive imagery — explosions, blood, or fighting — in ambiguous pictures.
items.rationale: Morbid and aggressive content (MOR, AG) are scored content-related special scores reflecting thematic preoccupation.

items.text: When I describe what I see in an inkblot, I usually talk about nature scenes — mountains, lakes, trees, and landscapes.
items.rationale: Nature and landscape content (Na, Ls) are specific content categories in Rorschach coding.

items.text: I notice that my interpretations of ambiguous images often involve sexual or intimate themes.
items.rationale: Sex content (Sx) is a specific content category that reflects thematic preoccupation with sexual material.

items.text: I am more likely to see everyday household objects — lamps, clothing, tools — than living creatures in random shapes.
items.rationale: Household and object content (Hh) is a content category reflecting concrete, mundane percepts.

items.text: My descriptions of ambiguous images tend to include mythological or fantastical beings like dragons, witches, or angels.
items.rationale: Fictional or mythological human/animal content (Hd, (H), (A)) reflects the thematic nature of what is perceived.

items.text: I often see food-related images — fruit, meat, or cooked dishes — when looking at abstract patterns.
items.rationale: Food content (Fd) is a specific content code reflecting oral or dependency-related thematic material.

items.text: When I look at inkblots, I tend to describe maps, geographic formations, or scientific diagrams.
items.rationale: Geography (Ge) and Science (Sc) content categories capture the thematic subject matter of the response.

items.text: I notice I rarely see human beings in ambiguous images — my responses are almost always about objects or abstract things.
items.rationale: Low human content (H) is clinically meaningful and reflects interpersonal disinterest or avoidance; this is a content-level observation.

items.text: I sometimes see partial human features — just a hand, an eye, or a profile — rather than whole people in ambiguous images.
items.rationale: Human detail content (Hd) is a content code, but the emphasis on partial vs. whole could also relate to Location (detail vs. whole).

items.text: The things I see in inkblots tend to be emotionally charged — scenes of death, celebration, or conflict rather than neutral objects.
items.rationale: Emotionally charged content themes are scored in content categories (MOR, AG, COP), though emotional reactivity could also relate to color-driven Determinants.

items.text: I see a pair of creatures interacting with each other — they seem to be dancing or fighting together.
items.rationale: The 'what' (creatures) is Content, but the perceived interaction (COP, AG) and implied movement could map to Determinants (M — human movement).

items.text: The colors in an ambiguous image strongly influence what I see — a red area becomes fire, a green area becomes a forest.
items.rationale: Chromatic color (FC, CF, C) is a core determinant category reflecting how color drives the percept.

items.text: I am drawn to the shading and texture in images — things look soft, furry, rough, or smooth to me.
items.rationale: Texture responses (T, FT, TF) are determinant codes reflecting sensitivity to shading as tactile quality.

items.text: When I look at inkblots, I see things in motion — people dancing, animals running, objects spinning.
items.rationale: Movement determinants (M, FM, m) are core determinant codes reflecting perceived kinesthetic activity.

items.text: The overall shape and form of the blot is what matters most to me — I match what I see to the contours of the image.
items.rationale: Form (F) is the most basic determinant, reflecting reliance on shape/contour to justify a percept.

items.text: I often perceive depth and dimensionality in flat images — things look like they recede into the distance or come toward me.
items.rationale: Vista (V, FV, VF) and dimensionality determinants reflect the use of shading to perceive depth.

items.text: Dark and light contrasts in an image make me see things as shadowy, ominous, or diffuse — like fog or smoke.
items.rationale: Diffuse shading (Y, FY, YF) is a determinant reflecting sensitivity to achromatic shading gradients.

items.text: I tend to use the black, white, and gray tones of an image to determine what I see, not just the colored parts.
items.rationale: Achromatic color (C', FC', C'F) is a determinant reflecting the use of black/white/gray as a color feature.

items.text: My responses to ambiguous images are almost entirely based on shape — color, shading, and texture don't really influence me.
items.rationale: Pure Form (F) dominance in the determinant profile (high Lambda/F%) is a key determinant-level finding.

items.text: I see animals that appear to be leaping or flying — the sense of movement is what makes the image come alive for me.
items.rationale: Animal movement (FM) is a specific determinant code reflecting perceived motion in animal figures.

items.text: I notice that bright colors pull my attention and shape my interpretation before I even consider the outline of the image.
items.rationale: Color-dominant responses (CF, C) indicate that chromatic features override form in determining the percept.

items.text: I perceive inanimate forces in the image — things look like they are falling, exploding, or being pulled apart.
items.rationale: Inanimate movement (m) is a determinant reflecting perceived motion in non-living objects or forces.

items.text: The reflections and symmetry of the inkblot make me see mirror images — things reflected in water or looking at themselves.
items.rationale: Reflection (Fr, rF) is a determinant based on the symmetry of the blot producing mirror-image percepts.

items.text: I can almost feel the weight and substance of what I see — some areas look heavy and dense while others seem light and airy.
items.rationale: This taps shading and texture determinants (T, Y, V) but the description is somewhat abstract and could overlap with content themes.

items.text: The way the ink blends from dark to light makes me see three-dimensional objects — it's the gradient that creates the image for me.
items.rationale: Clearly references shading-based determinants (FV, FY, FT), though the emphasis on 'objects' could slightly invoke content.

items.text: I see two human figures in the center of the image, and the way they are posed makes them look like they are bowing to each other.
items.rationale: The perceived movement (bowing) is a Determinant (M), but 'two human figures' is Content (H) and 'center of the image' references Location.

items.text: I tend to use the entire inkblot as a whole to form my interpretation rather than focusing on individual parts.
items.rationale: Whole response (W) is a primary location code indicating the respondent uses the entire blot.

items.text: I usually focus on one specific, commonly identified section of the image rather than trying to interpret everything at once.
items.rationale: Common detail (D) is a location code reflecting focus on frequently selected blot areas.

items.text: I notice tiny, unusual areas of the inkblot that most people overlook — small edges, gaps, or irregular spots.
items.rationale: Unusual detail (Dd) is a location code reflecting attention to rarely selected, small, or idiosyncratic blot areas.

items.text: I focus on the white space inside or around the inkblot rather than the ink itself.
items.rationale: Space responses (S) are a location code reflecting use of the white background as the figure.

items.text: I like to step back and see the big picture — I integrate all parts of the image into one coherent interpretation.
items.rationale: Synthesized whole responses (W+, DQ+) reflect integrative location use combining multiple areas into a unified percept.

items.text: I tend to break the image down into separate sections and give a different response for each part.
items.rationale: Multiple detail responses (D, Dd) with separate percepts reflect a fragmented, part-focused location approach.

items.text: I am drawn to the central axis of the inkblot and build my interpretation around what I see along the midline.
items.rationale: Central detail selection is a location-level observation about which area of the blot is chosen.

items.text: I often combine the white space with the inked areas to create a single, integrated image.
items.rationale: Space integration (WS, DS) is a location code reflecting combined use of figure and ground.

items.text: I gravitate toward the outer edges and periphery of the inkblot rather than the center.
items.rationale: Edge detail (Dd) selection at the periphery is a location-level coding decision about blot area used.

items.text: When I try to use the whole blot, my interpretation feels vague and poorly defined — I do better with smaller sections.
items.rationale: Vague whole responses (Wv, DQv) versus well-articulated detail responses reflect location selection and developmental quality.

items.text: I see one thing in the top half of the image and something completely different in the bottom half — they don't connect for me.
items.rationale: Separate detail responses to distinct blot regions reflect a location-driven approach to segmenting the stimulus.

items.text: I almost never use the white spaces — I only pay attention to where the ink actually is.
items.rationale: Absence of space responses (low S) is a location-level observation about figure-ground processing.

items.text: I pick out a small, unusual area of the blot and see something very specific and detailed there that nobody else notices.
items.rationale: Unusual detail (Dd) with high specificity is primarily location, but the uniqueness of the percept could also relate to unusual content.

items.text: I try to incorporate every part of the blot into my response, but the shape doesn't quite fit what I'm describing.
items.rationale: This describes a whole response (W) with poor form quality; primarily location (W) but form quality touches on Determinants (F-).

items.text: I focus on a large, obvious section of the blot and see a brightly colored butterfly with its wings spread wide.
items.rationale: The area selection (large obvious section) is Location (D), but 'brightly colored' invokes Determinants (FC/CF) and 'butterfly' is Content (A).
